Sure, let me say that again
Oligopoly model in which each firm chooses its production quantity
Positive science is concerned with the question of how people deal with the phenomenon of scarcity.
Normarive science is concerend with how people should deal with the phenomenon of scarcity.
Microeconomics is the study of decision-making of households and firms and the interaction between economic agents.
A theory is a reasonable conjecture about the cuntioning of some aspects of the world.
Oligopoly model in which each firm chooses the price of its product
Reasonable means that there is a consensus among scientists about acceptable methods and procedures.
Macroeconomics foucuses on the functioning of the economy as a whole
A strategy that is the best for a firm, no matter what strategies other firms use
A situation in which economic actors interacting with one another each choose their best strategy given the strategies that all the other actors have chosen
The pork cycle describes an economic phenomenon on the interaction level which deals with the interaction between people and firms
It gives the best response for all possible strategies of all other players
The circular/flow model explains that, within an economy consisting solely of private households and firms, the sum of expenses for consumption must equal the income factors
A particular game between two captured prisoners that illustrates why cooperation is difficult to maintain even when it is mutually beneficial
The study of how people behave in strategic situations
Opportunity cost is the loss of potential gain from choosing one alternative over another.
There are normal and extensive games
Sale of 2 or more separate products in one package
The goal of economics is to maximise utility and hence minimise opportunity costs.
Sunk costs are costs that have already been incurred and cannot be recovered.
Charging each individual customer a different price based on their willingness to pay. There is no consumer surplus!
Occurs when consumers are charged different prices based on characteristics of their purchase e.g. phone bill
Charging different prices to different demographic market segments

The theory of comparative advantage contends that a country should make and then sell those products it produces most efficiently but buy those it cannot produce as efficiently (why do individuals trade?)
Autarky describes a situatino in which a country does not trade with other countries and is entirely independent..
A country with comparative disadvantage in the production of a good should import such good from other countries. It may specialise and export a good for which it has a comparative advantage.
It measures the effect on the change of revenue by price change
p'(x) * x
It measures the effect on revenue by increasing quantity
A bilateral monopoly is a market with just one single seller and only one single buyer
In perfect competitions, any individual firm is so small that it cannot influence the equilibrium price. Therefore firms are price-takers
A market in which is only one seller but few buyers
A monopoly is a market in which are many buyers but only one seller.
As a price-maker since they control the market price. However, it has to consider the actual elasticity of the market demand function
A market with few sellers but only one buyer
A market with few buyers and few sellers
The extra cost incurred by producing one more unit of a product
An oligopoly is a market with few sellers and many buyers
A market in which are many sellers but only one buyer
AFC = FC / Q
A market with many sellers and few buyers.
A polypoly is a market characterised by many sellers and many buyers.
AVC = FC / Q
Total costs per unit of output
It measures by how much production increases if another unit of a factor (input) is employed
dx/dl= dF(I)/ dl
With a given number of firms, it represents the sum of individual supplies. With free market entry and exit, market supply curve is perfectly elastic at the price equalling minimum AC (MC = AC)
Goods that are neither excludable nor rival in consumption
Goods that are non excludable but rivalrous e.g. oxygen, radioactivity, surface of the moon, etc.
Goods that are both excludable and rival in consumption e.g. apples
The costs in time and other resources that parties incur in the process of agreeing to and carrying out an exchange of goods and services
A measure of how much the quantity supplied of a good responds to a change in the price of that good, computed as the percentage change in quantity supplied divided by the percentage change in price
A measure by what percentage will the demand for good i change when the income of individuals increases by 1%?
A measure of how much the quantity demanded of a good responds to a change in the price of that good, computed as the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price
Adam Smith published his most popular book The wealth of Nations in 1776
Adam Smith is well known for his book The wealth of Nations in which he described how a capitalist, free market economic system works.

Adam Smith was a Scottish economist, philosopher as well as a moral philosopher, a pioneer of political economy, and a key figure during the Scottish Enlightenment, also known as ''The Father of Economics'' or ''The Father of Capitalism''
